Invocation
Items.AgendaNote:
Delivered by: Father Raymond Nobiletti, Church of the Transfiguration, Roman Catholic, 25 Mott Street, New York, N.Y. 10013.

Motion to spread the invocation in full upon the record by Council Member Chin.

The Invocation was delivered by: Father Raymond Nobiletti, Church of the Transfiguration, Roman Catholic, 25 Mott Street, New York, N.Y. 10013.



Council Member Chin moved to spread the Invocation in full upon the Record.

Items.Title: Adoption of Minutes
Items.AgendaNote: Motion that the Minutes of the Stated Meeting of December 17, 2014 be adopted as printed by Council Member Barron.
Items.MinutesNote: Council Member Barron moved that the Minutes of the Stated Meeting of December 17, 2014 be adopted as printed.

Items.Title: Messages & Papers from the Mayor

Communication from the Mayor - Submitting the name of Wellington Chen to the Council for its advice and consent regarding his appointment as a member of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, pursuant to Sections 31 and 3020 of the New York City Charter.

Items.MatterName: Kim Vauss, Landmarks Preservation Commission

Items.Title: Communication from the Mayor - Submitting the name of Hank Willis Thomas to the Council for its advice and consent regarding his appointment as the painter member of the New York City Art Commission, known as Public Design Commission, pursuant to Sections 31 and 851 of the New York City Charter.

Items.Title: Land Use Call-Ups

By Council Member Johnson:
Pursuant to Rule 11.20b of the Council and §20-226 or §20-225 of the New York City Administrative Code, the Council resolves that the action of the Department of Consumer Affairs approving an unenclosed sidewalk café located at 89 MacDougal Street, Borough of Manhattan, Community Board No. 2, Application No.  20155146 TCM shall be subject to review by the Council.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Land Use Call-Up be Approved, by Council approved by Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Zoning, 89 MacDougal St, Manhattan (20155146 TCM)

A Local Law in relation to the naming of 56 thoroughfares and public places, Dave Reid Jr. Place, Borough of the Bronx, Prince Joshua Avitto Way, Borough of Brooklyn, Rev. Wenceslao Martinez Way, Borough of Brooklyn, José Francisco Peña Gomez Boulevard, Borough of the Bronx, DJ Scott la Rock Boulevard, Borough of the Bronx, Luis Muñoz Marín Way, Borough of the Bronx, Basil Paterson Boulevard, Borough of the Bronx, Oscar de la Renta Boulevard, Borough of the Bronx, Frank T. Santo Way, Borough of Brooklyn, Judge Hansel L. McGee Place, Borough of the Bronx, Bishop Robert Green Way, Borough of the Bronx, Angelo “Chubby” Campanella, Borough of Brooklyn, Rabbi Weissmandl Way, Borough of Brooklyn, Jimmy Zappalorti Lane, Borough of Staten Island, FDNY Lt. Matt Ambelas Way, Borough of Staten Island, Milton Alexander Way, Borough of the Bronx, Bishop Ignatius A. Lohnes Way, Borough of Queens, Sunnyside Garden Arena Way, Borough of Queens, Alice Cardona Way, Borough of Queens, Luke Adams Way, Borough of Queens, Pecola and Nicholas Rodriguez Way, Borough of Brooklyn, Debbie Bowden Way, Borough of the Bronx, Margaret Mack Triangle, Borough of the Bronx and the repeal of sections 14, 15, 24, 25, 40 and 62 of local law number 34 for the year 2014, sections 34 and 53 of local law number 131 for the year 2013 and section 46 of local law number 50 for the year 2013.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to providing tenants with information regarding the senior citizens rent increase exemption and the disability rent increase exemption.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Providing tenants with information regarding the senior citizens rent increase exemption and the disability rent increase exemption.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Board of Trustees of the State University of New York to require a new application and public hearing when the designated community school district in a charter school application changes.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education
Items.MatterName: Board of Trustees of the State University of NY to require a new application and public hearing when the designated community school district in a charter school application changes.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to introduce and pass, and the Governor to sign, legislation establishing a property tax credit for commercial landlords who voluntarily limit the amount of rent increases to small business owner tenants upon lease renewal.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: Establishing a property tax credit for commercial landlords who voluntarily limit the amount of rent increases to small business owner tenants upon lease renewal.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of homeless services to educate homeless persons on domestic violence
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on General Welfare
Items.MatterName: Requiring the dept of homeless services to educate homeless persons on domestic violence.

Items.Title: Resolution urging the United States Department of Education and Arne Duncan, Secretary of Education, to reconsider the “Gainful Employment” rule that as proposed could derail the educational careers of millions of Americans and have a disproportionately negative effect on low-income and minority students who want to attend college.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Higher Education
Items.MatterName: DOE and Arne Duncan, Secretary of Education, to reconsider the “Gainful Employment” rule.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the United States Senate to ratify the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW).
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Women's Issues
Items.MatterName: Senate to ratify the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW).

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the United States Congress to pass legislation to protect a woman’s health, her right to determine whether and when to bear a child, and her ability to exercise that right by limiting government interference with the provision of abortion services and ensuring legal, safe abortion care is available to any woman who needs it.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Women's Issues
Items.MatterName: Protect a woman’s health, her right to determine whether and when to bear a child, and her ability to exercise that right by limiting government interference.

Items.Title: Resolution approving the new designation and changes in the designation of certain organizations to receive funding in the Expense Budget.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: Approving the new designation and changes in the designation of certain organizations to receive funding in the Expense Budget.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the curbs adjacent to a fire hydrant or bus stop.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Curbs adjacent to a fire hydrant or bus stop.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York State Legislature to pass and Governor to sign legislation requiring New York State Homes and Community Renewal to collect succession rights data from property owners and release a summary of the statistics to the public.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Requiring NYS Homes and Community Renewal to collect succession rights data from property owners and release a summary of the statistics to the public.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring owners of residential property with six to ten units to submit income and expense statements.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: Requiring owners of residential property with six to ten units to submit income and expense statements.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York City Rent Guidelines Board to discontinue consideration of the Price Index of Operating Costs in assessing the economic condition of the residential real estate industry to determine the annual rent adjustments for dwelling units subject to the Rent Stabilization Law.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Rent Guidelines Board to discontinue consideration of the Price Index of Operating Costs.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to securing personal information privacy.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Technology
Items.MatterName: Securing personal information privacy.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to personal information security.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Technology
Items.MatterName: Personal information security.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York in relation to improving young adults’ access to voter registration materials by requiring the department of education of the city of New York and the board of elections of the city of New York to provide students with registration materials in appropriate languages and to track and report on the efficacy of distributing registration materials to students.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations
Items.MatterName: Improving young adults’ access to voter registration materials.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to housing accommodations and tenant black lists.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Civil Rights
Items.MatterName: Housing accommodations and tenant black lists.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the length of the season for city beaches and pools
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Parks and Recreation
Items.MatterName: Length of the season for city beaches and pools.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter, in relation to improving security in schools on election days.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education
Items.MatterName: Improving security in schools on election days.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to prohibiting the issuance of multiple bus lane violation tickets for the same infraction within a one hour period.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Prohibiting the issuance of multiple bus lane violation tickets for the same infraction within a one hour period.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring energy efficiency reports to be filed every five years.

Items.MatterName: Requiring energy efficiency reports to be filed every five years.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on Governor Andrew Cuomo to veto the application by Liberty Natural Gas, LLC to construct the Port Ambrose liquefied natural gas terminal off the coast of New York.

Items.MatterName: Governor Andrew Cuomo to veto the application by Liberty Natural Gas, LLC to construct the Port Ambrose liquefied natural gas terminal off the coast of NY.

Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Environmental Protection
Items.MatterName: NY Power Authority to permanently set a competitive electricity rate at the Brooklyn Cruise Terminal.

Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health
Items.MatterName: Recognize “Meatless Monday” in NYC.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to suspending alternate side parking regulations on primary election day.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Suspending alternate side parking regulations on primary election day.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the Federal Emergency Management Agency to re-examine all National Flood Insurance Program insurance claim payouts related to Hurricane Sandy for possible underpayment, and to henceforth require insurance companies to make available to flood insurance claimants all drafts of engineering reports that are used in the assessment of damages.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Recovery and Resiliency
Items.MatterName: Federal Emergency Management Agency to re-examine all National Flood Insurance Program insurance claim payouts related to Hurricane Sandy for possible underpayment.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the City of New York, in relation to creating a civil penalty for any individual who is convicted of fraud or property related crimes that occur in a mandatory evacuation zone during a mandatory evacuation period.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Creating a civil penalty for any individual who is convicted of fraud or property related crimes that occur in a mandatory evacuation zone during a mandatory evacuation period.

Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Technology

Items.Title: Resolution declaring January 15th - 22nd of each year as Peace Week in the City of New York.
Items.AgendaNote: Adopted by the Committee on Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Intergroup Relations
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. James) called for a voice vote.  Hearing no objections, the Public Advocate (Ms. James) declared the Resolution to be adopted.


Adopted unanimously by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.MatterName: Declaring January 15th - 22nd of each year as Peace Week in NYC.

Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. James) called for a voice vote.  Hearing no objections, the Public Advocate (Ms. James) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

Items.Title: Resolution recognizing January as Cervical Health Awareness Month in New York City.

Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. James) called for a voice vote.  Hearing no objections, the Public Advocate (Ms. James) declared the Resolution to be adopted.


Adopted unanimously by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.MatterName: Recognizing January as Cervical Health Awareness Month in NYC.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to pass legislation permitting health care practitioners to provide treatment to youth for the prevention of human papillomavirus, a common virus that can cause cancer.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Health
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. James) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Public Advocate (Ms. James) declared the Resolution to be adopted.



The following 2 Council Members formally voted against this item: Council Members Matteo and Ignizio.



Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.MatterName: Permitting health care practitioners to provide treatment to youth for the prevention of human papillomavirus, a common virus that can cause cancer.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the United States Congress to pass legislation to protect a woman’s health, her right to determine whether and when to bear a child, and her ability to exercise that right by limiting government interference with the provision of abortion services and ensuring legal, safe abortion care is available to any woman who needs it.
Items.AgendaNote: Preconsidered - Adopted by the Committee on Women's Issues
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. James) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Public Advocate (Ms. James) declared the Resolution to be adopted.



The following 4 Council Members formally voted against this item:  Council Members Cabrera, Matteo, Vallone, and Ignizio..



The following 2 Council Members formally abstained to vote on this item:  Council Members Ulrich and Williams.

Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.MatterName: Protect a woman’s health, her right to determine whether and when to bear a child, and her ability to exercise that right by limiting government interference.
